awd_titl_txt: Electrical control of nontrivial textures in magnetic nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: 
The technological demand for smaller and faster devices capable of new functionalities drives the scientific exploration of the nontrivial states of matter that remain stable when scaled down to just a few nanometers. The Project studies the skyrmions - nontrivial nanoscale magnetic textures that cannot by annihilated by a continuous evolution of magnetization. Such textures can be as small as a few nanometers, making it difficult to study them by the conventional microscopy techniques, and consequently very little is known about their properties or how they can be used in nanodevices. The Project uses magnetoelectronic measurements in nanofabricated structures to access the relevant length sales, and investigate the possibility to use electrical current locally injected into ultrathin magnetic films to create, manipulate, and detect skyrmions. The research is integrated with the training for undergraduate and graduate students, and contributes to the burgeoning broader nanoscience research, education and outreach efforts in the Atlanta area.

Technical description: 
The Project investigates magnetic skyrmions - topologically nontrivial states in magnetic materials, which cannot be obtained by a continuous transformation of "trivial" states, and thus exhibit higher stability, unusual dynamical characteristics and response to perturbations. The research utilizes nanofabricated magnetic nanostructures based on ultrathin magnetic films with perpendicular anisotropy, and magnetoelectronic techniques to generate, characterize, and manipulate both static and dynamical states of skyrmions by electrical current. Materials science and magnetic engineering are used to achieve a significant Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya interaction capable of stabilizing skyrmions in the absence of current. New measurement approaches, such as three-terminal Hall effect , are designed specifically to investigate phenomena on nanoscale not accessible with the established techniques. This research provides fundamental insight into the effects of topological textures on the material properties, and develops routes for their experimental exploration as well as possible applications in nanoscale magnetoelectronic (spintronic) devices. In addition to directly training two graduate students, the impact of the Project is significantly enhanced by its role in supporting the free shared condensed matter and nanoscience research facilities provided by the PI to researchers at Emory University and in the larger Atlanta area, research involvement of undergraduates and high school students, and contribution the large special events such as the Atlanta Science Festival and the Elementary School Science Day.

por.por_cntn:
The project investigated the possibility to control and detect the dynamic and static states of nanomagnetic systems, with the goal of developing magnetoelectronic devices for the emerging novel computing schemes. The specific questions of scientific and practical significance addressed by the project were:

i)                  What fundamental mechanisms enable electronic control of nanomagnetic systems?

ii)                How does the magnetic geometry, the spin injection geometry, and the magnetic properties of the system affect the characteristics of the static states and the dynamical modes induced by spin currents?

iii)               Can complex magnetization states such as magnetic textures be generated and stabilized by engineering thin-film magnetic heterostructures?

The intellectual merit of the project is the advancement in the fundamental understanding of nanomagnetism, magnetoelectronic, and magneto-optical phenomena, as follows:

i)                  Among the new findings elucidating the mechanisms enabling electronic control of nanomagnetic systems are: (a) discovery of the quantum spin transfer effect, which can provide a significant contribution to high-frequency current-induced magnetization dynamics, and (b) discovery of Dyakonov-Perel-like spin-orbit relaxation mechanism in Pt, likely elucidating the same spin-orbit interaction mechanisms as those underlying the spin Hall effect (SHE), (c) Demonstration of the possibility to modulate spin-orbit effects (and consequently spectral characteristics) in spin Hall nano-oscillators (SHNO) by electric field, (d) Demonstration of quasi-equilibrium magnon distribution in spin current-driven nanostructures, providing a fundamental connection to the Bose-Einstein condensation.

ii)                Among the findings that elucidate the relationship among the geometry, the magnetic properties, and the spin-current induced dynamical/static magnetization states are: (a) profiling of magnetic films was shown to enable controllable modification of local spin wave characteristics, which allows engineering of active nanomagnonic devices capable of generating directionally propagating coherent spin waves. This approach has been demonstrated for nanodevices based on nononlocal spin injection and SHE. In the latter case, the possibility to enhance spin wave propagation by spin injection was also demonstrated, (b) the possibility to stabilize different quasi-linear and solitonic dynamical states of magnetization was demonstrated, the latter including spin wave bullets, solitons with p-wave symmetry, stationary and propagating magnetic droplets, and more complex multimodal states, as well as dynamical chaos, (c) the possibility to synchronize magnetic oscillators (mutually and to external signals) by engineering magnetic geometry and spectral characteristics was demonstrated

iii)               It was established that magnetic frustration at the interfaces of sufficiently thin films of materials with incompatible magnetic ordering - ferromagnets (F) and antiferromagnets (AF) - results in the formation of new magnetic phases of matter, such as magnetic liquids and magnetic glasses. These phases can stabilize magnetic textures and other complex magnetization states

 The broader impacts of the project included i) scientific and technical training of the project participants, relevant to both academic/research and high-tech industrial careers; ii) fundamental advancement of nanomagnetism; iii) development and characterization of hybrid materials and structures that can form the basis for novel computational technologies, such as magnonics and neuromorphic computing; iv) Education and increased scientific involvement of the general public through the outreach events that included the Atlanta Science Festival, hands-one science classes for elementary school, as well as research involvement of high-school students.

The project was transformative for our understanding of the relationship among the structure, the geometry, the magnetic properties, and the possible functionalities of nanomagnetic systems.
